another related area which is stuff like documentation and tooling and Automation and um like sort of like what are the
required things that you should have in a project um or or what's a good like standard way of setting up your project
and make it easy for people to come in um even if and and just like create as little work as possible for you um so I
think all that stuff is a big important part of the sustainability conversation um diving more into I guess
funding models or things that have worked MoneyWise I think there's a lot of experimentation happening there right

in this space at least once a week right now um which I guess is not super high

um paying them out and and sort of like what's the like volume of money you're
trying to pay here like I think this that's the hardest part about introducing money to open sour is if you
there a lot of these like sort of like smaller um you know if you pay out a couple dollars to anyone who commits a
certain number of lines of code like is that actually a great incentive or not
it could make things worse if you're talking about paying someone tens of thousands of dollars or hundreds of
thousands of dollars and that's a very different kind of a game um so I still find all those Dynamics really
interesting um and thinking about what funding models are actually viable or not a couple of the I guess within that
the the question is sort of like well what are people paying for and what's worth paying for
and I see it break down into um people that are sponsoring a project so it's
kind of like more of an open sponsorship visibility kind of thing um so like a company might want their logo on a
project or something like that that's one of experimentation one is around licenses I think that conversation will
probably go on forever um about like can you use a license to encourage someone
to to pay um which is kind of interesting like I I want to be sort of like NH who knows um but it's very like
persistent so who knows what'll happen that space um and then the other one other big area I see is like support and
services um of yeah can we guarantee some level of quality or um
responsiveness or have your issues prioritized or something like that and yeah have that kind of like be the third
area of um something worth paying for but yeah those are the areas I'm seeing
a lot of experimentation in yeah yeah I I think that that's a good way to kind of categorize them um I I will say that
I I've been very very surprised by both the success and and kind of failure
cases that we've seen um and also what the reaction of older open source people has been to these experiments um it's
been almost universally negative um like and I I have a hard time trying to
figure out why they've been so negative about it um it it tends to be that they are adate that big companies not have
formal relationships in these projects whether that's through sponsorship or putting their logo up or anything they they want some kind of like plausible
deniability between the contributor and the company the odd thing is that almost
universally these people are employed by those big companies so they they have like the most um all of the unofficial
relationships and all of the kind of like background influence is really prevalent in all of these older projects
and older open source people um and um and and they are you know really adamant
that that not be formalized in any way which is suspect to me um really suspect
whether it's implicit or explicit the influence is still there either way right right and and I also think like
you know we we interviewed um you know a couple people that did open Collective stuff and we interviewed evu who did uh
patreon right and what we heard from these people was the opposite of what I
thought that we would hear so you have people that are funding the project and then you have people that are funding individuals like through patreon and I
thought that if you had people funding individuals there wouldn't be as much of an incentive to bring on new contributors because you're already
funding this one person and but what we saw was that that was actually kind of the worst when you were funding the project because then people were
fighting over kind of control of the project because that's where the funding is coming in or they're fighting over how to Dole out that money and which
kind of person gets it whereas when you fund the individual like when you fund Evan you on patreon you're not funding
VJs you're funding Evan there's an expectation already from everybody that put in money that this goes to Evan um
and then Evan is part of it I think that is just his personality like he's he wants to bring in new people and and
create a really big community um but also you know he's he's stable enough with his relationship to that
sustainability like the check that is feeding his family is coming directly to him so he doesn't have to hold his project hostage he can always do what's

um I don't I yeah we're only human we're going to have finite level of interest and things sometimes and I don't think

so yeah and I think the the one Dynamic that will get interesting if we focus on

original author or maintainer is not transparent about how much work they're actually doing then yeahh makes sense I
I feel like in general a topic that I'd like to see a lot more kind of conference talks about and a lot more
just discussion about is how to how to leave how to walk away from something
responsibly um well both like you know how it's it's actually better for the project for you to be less involved most
